content.definition: Charcot-Bouchard Microaneurysms are minute aneurysms occurring in small, deep penetrating vessels (typically the [[lenticulostriate_arteries]]) caused by chronic hypertension, which leads to lipohyalinosis and fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall, predisposing to rupture and [[intraparenchymal_hemorrhage]].
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Chronic [[hypertension]] causing hyaline arteriosclerosis.
  • Location: Deep brain structures: Basal ganglia (Putamen/Globus Pallidus), Thalamus, Pons, Cerebellum.
  • Complication: Rupture leads to hemorrhagic stroke (intraparenchymal bleed).
  • Imaging: Hyperdense collection on CT; aneurysms themselves are often too small to be seen on angiography.
  • USMLE Tip: Contrast with [[saccular_aneurysm]] (Berry): Charcot-Bouchard = Chronic HTN, Small vessels, Intraparenchymal bleed. Berry = ADPKD/Ehlers-Danlos, Circle of Willis, Subarachnoid bleed.
content.takeAway: These microaneurysms are the pathological link between chronic uncontrolled hypertension and deep [[intraparenchymal_hemorrhage]], specifically affecting the lenticulostriate vessels supplying the [[basal_ganglia]].

content.definition: The Abducens Nerve (CN VI) is a purely motor cranial nerve originating from the [[pons]] that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction (lateral movement) of the eye.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Pons (facial colliculus).
  • Pathway: Exits at pontomedullary junction → travels through [[cavernous_sinus]] → enters orbit via [[superior_orbital_fissure]].
  • Function: Innervates Lateral Rectus (LR).
  • Lesion: Medial strabismus (eye turns in), diplopia, inability to abduct eye.
  • USMLE Tip: The 'Chemical Formula' for eye muscles: LR6SO4R3 (Lateral Rectus = CN VI, Superior Oblique = CN IV, Rest = CN III).
content.takeAway: CN VI has the longest subarachnoid course of all cranial nerves, making it highly susceptible to injury from elevated [[intracranial_pressure]] (false localizing sign).

content.definition: Subacute Combined Degeneration is a progressive degeneration of the spinal cord caused by [[vitamin_b12_deficiency]], characterized by demyelination of the dorsal columns (sensory), lateral corticospinal tracts (motor), and spinocerebellar tracts (coordination).
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Vitamin B12 deficiency (Pernicious anemia, Gastric bypass, Veganism, Diphyllobothrium latum).
  • Pathology: Demyelination of Dorsal Columns + Lateral Corticospinal Tracts + Spinocerebellar Tracts.
  • Symptoms: Paresthesias, ataxia, loss of vibration/proprioception, spastic paresis.
  • Labs: ↑ Serum [[homocysteine]] and ↑ [[methylmalonic_acid]].
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[tabes_dorsalis]] (Syphilis) which affects only dorsal columns (no motor signs) and lacks the megaloblastic anemia.
content.takeAway: The term 'Combined' refers to the simultaneous involvement of both sensory (dorsal column) and motor (corticospinal) pathways, a specific hallmark of B12 deficiency myelopathy.

content.definition: Absence Seizures (formerly petit mal) are a type of generalized seizure primarily affecting children, characterized by brief (seconds), sudden lapses of consciousness ('blank stare') without loss of postural tone or postictal confusion.
content.atAGlance:
• EEG Finding: Classic 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges.
  • Clinical: Child stops activity, stares blankly, may have lip smacking or eye fluttering; no memory of event; immediate recovery.
  • Triggers: Hyperventilation or flashing lights.
  • Treatment: First-line is [[ethosuximide]]; second-line [[valproic_acid]].
  • USMLE Tip: Distinguish from 'daydreaming' by the lack of response to touch/voice during the event and the specific EEG pattern.
content.takeAway: Unlike other seizure types, absence seizures uniquely lack a postictal state and are specifically treated with [[ethosuximide]] which blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus.

content.definition: Ethosuximide is a narrow-spectrum anticonvulsant that functions by blocking T-type calcium channels in [[thalamus]] neurons, preventing the synchronized burst firing responsible for absence seizures.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Blocks T-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Clinical Use: First-line for [[absence_seizure]].
  • Adverse Effects: EFGHIJ mnemonic: Ethosuximide causes Fatigue, GI distress, Headache, Itching (and urticaria), and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient has both absence and tonic-clonic seizures, use [[valproic_acid]] instead (broad spectrum). Ethosuximide is for absence ONLY.
content.takeAway: It is the quintessential drug for 'blank stare' seizures because it specifically targets the thalamocortical oscillations generated by T-type calcium channels.

content.definition: Abnormal Motor Posturing refers to involuntary flexion or extension of the limbs in comatose patients, serving as a critical indicator of the level of brain injury relative to the [[red_nucleus]].
content.atAGlance:
• Decorticate (Flexor): Arms flexed/adducted ('hands to core'), legs extended. Lesion is above the red nucleus (Cerebral hemispheres, Internal capsule).
  • Decerebrate (Extensor): Arms extended/pronated, legs extended. Lesion is at or below the red nucleus (Midbrain, Pons).
  • Prognosis: Decerebrate is worse.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember Decorticate = Hands near the Cor (Heart).
content.takeAway: The distinction relies on the Rubrospinal tract (originating in the Red Nucleus); if the tract is intact (lesion above), it facilitates flexion (Decorticate). If the nucleus is damaged or disconnected (lesion below), the vestibulospinal tract dominates, causing extension (Decerebrate).

content.definition: Noncommunicating (Obstructive) Hydrocephalus is a type of hydrocephalus caused by a structural blockage of [[cerebrospinal_fluid]] (CSF) flow within the ventricular system, preventing it from reaching the subarachnoid space for resorption.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Physical obstruction of CSF flow.
  • Common Causes: Stenosis of [[cerebral_aqueduct]], Colloid cyst blocking [[foramen_of_monro]], Tumors (e.g., Ependymoma, Medulloblastoma).
  • Imaging: Ventricles 'upstream' of the block are dilated; those 'downstream' are normal.
  • Clinical: Headache, papilledema, nausea/vomiting, potential herniation.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[communicating_hydrocephalus]] where all ventricles are dilated due to resorption failure (arachnoid granulations).
content.takeAway: The hallmark is disproportionate dilation of the ventricular system proximal to the site of obstruction, most commonly at the narrow cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.

content.definition: The Accessory Nerve (CN XI) is a purely motor cranial nerve that originates from the upper spinal cord (C1-C5), enters the skull via the foramen magnum, and exits via the [[jugular_foramen]] to innervate the Sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and Trapezius muscles.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Head turning (SCM) and shoulder shrugging (Trapezius).
  • Pathway: Unique path: Ascends into skull → Exits skull via [[jugular_foramen]].
  • Lesion: Inability to shrug shoulder (ipsilateral); difficulty turning head to the contralateral side (since left SCM turns head right).
  • Vulnerable Spot: Posterior triangle of the neck (lymph node biopsy).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who cannot turn their head to the Right has a lesion of the Left CN XI (SCM).
content.takeAway: It is the only cranial nerve that originates from the spinal cord segments, enters the cranium, and then exits back to the neck, making it susceptible to injury during neck surgeries (e.g., radical neck dissection).

content.definition: Gerstmann Syndrome is a cognitive disorder resulting from a lesion to the dominant (usually Left) [[parietal_lobe]] (specifically the angular gyrus), characterized by a specific tetrad of deficits.
content.atAGlance:
• The Tetrad:
    1. Agraphia (inability to write)
    2. Acalculia (inability to calculate)
    3. Finger Agnosia (inability to distinguish fingers)
    4. Left-Right Disorientation.
  • Cause: Usually [[middle_cerebral_artery|MCA]] stroke affecting the angular gyrus.
  • USMLE Tip: Do not confuse with non-dominant parietal lesions, which cause [[hemispatial_neglect]].
content.takeAway: The syndrome highlights the dominant parietal lobe's critical role in multimodal sensory integration, specifically mapping sensory inputs to symbolic systems like language (writing) and math.

content.definition: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy) is an acute, autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves ([[schwann_cells]]), typically triggered by molecular mimicry following an infection (e.g., [[campylobacter_jejuni]]).
content.atAGlance:
• Presentation: Symmetric, ascending muscle weakness/paralysis and absent deep tendon reflexes (DTRs). May affect respiratory muscles (life-threatening) and autonomic nerves (arrhythmias).
  • Pathogenesis: Autoantibodies attack myelin or gangliosides; Endoneurial inflammation.
  • CSF Findings: Albuminocytologic Dissociation (↑ Protein with Normal WBC count).
  • Treatment: Plasmapheresis or [[ivig]]. Steroids are ineffective.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a history of bloody diarrhea (Campylobacter) or respiratory infection (Mycoplasma/Zika) weeks prior to weakness.
content.takeAway: The critical diagnostic clue is the albuminocytologic dissociation in the CSF, which reflects widespread nerve root inflammation without a direct CNS infection.
